THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

APRIL 23, 1902.

No, 14.

THE LOVE OF A LAD FOR A LASS.
HERE was the subdued hum of children studying in the small Virginia
school-room. From without came the chirping of a robin perched among
the blossoms of the peach tree that scraped its branches lazily against the
.
window of the school-house. By the side of the teacher, a young man, stood a
Slight, black-haired boy of ten, engrossed in the explanation of a sum on his
Slate. The heads of both master and scholar were bent over the slate, so that
neither noticed a boy in the back of the room quietly filling a squirt-gun from
the water-bucket. Twice or thrice at some slight noise the teacher glanced up
angrily, and once he knocked loudly on the desk with a ruler, but still the
little rascal with the gun went undetected; and, judging from the way the
smallest noise disturbed the teacher, it was well for the boy that his more repreprehensible act did go unnoticed. Then, while every pupil held his breath,
Partly in admiration, partly in fear, a thin stream of water shot across the room
and broke on the teacher's head, splashing over the book-covered desk before
him. Completely taken aback by the unexpected bath, the teacher sprang up,
anger flushing every feature, and made a step toward, to his mind, the one possible culprit, the boy who had been standing by the desk, but who had jumped
back, as much astonished at the splashing water as the teacher himself had been.
"Gordon Chapman," he burst out, "you did that!"
Slap! and Gordon was lying in a heap across the platform, his face sheetWhite except where four finger-marks blazed fiercely out.
"Stop! You— you— devil! Jordie didn't do it." As Gordon went to
the floor under his master's hand, a little red-haired girl of about his age, hurling at the teacher the vilest name she could think of, jumped on the platform,
and with childish rage attempted to dig her finger nails into his face.
"Don't, Bab, don't," Gordon pleaded weakly from the floor; "he'll slap
you, too. Stop!"
Seeing that the disturbance was developing into a rebellion, the teacher
calmed himself sufficiently to proclaim the dismission of school. "Gordon
Chapman will remain, though," he said, "and Miss Barbara's mother shall
know of her daughter's behavior before to-night." All of the scholars except
Bab. and Gordon gleefully departed; Bab tearfully and unwillingly stumbled
out the door, calling back words of consolation and encouragement to poor
Jorclie, who sat with pale cheeks but tightly held lips, awaiting whatever was
to come.
When two University students, alarmed by Bab's confused story, arrived
at the school-house half an hour later, they found Gordon, with bloody stripes

t

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

across the back of his shirt-waist, lying in a faint on the :floor, and by him a
broken rattan.
One afternoon of the following week, the school-room door was opened,
and Gordon Chapman, four blue bruises across his face, walked somewhat uncertainly up the aisle, under the wondering gaze of his schoolmates.
"Mr. Lindsay," he said, as strongly as he could, "I'm not coming here
any longer to school, but I'll never forget you; and as soon as I am able I am
going to kill you."
As he strode down the aisle, now with a manly step, and passed out the
door, no one made a sound except that a little red-haired girl cried softly, "0
Jordie, Jordiel"
Eight years had passed since Gordon Chapman had made his promise to
Roger Lindsay; the great Civil War was just beginning, and many tented
cities, peopled with Virginia's sons, both young and old, had sprung up as in
a single night. It was about five o'clock of a warm August afternoon; a boy,
not quite grown, wearing the uniform of a Confederate private, was riding
slowly along the wooded road, singing an old love song. Presently he stopped
singing and began to calculate.
"Let's see, three days' leave, beginning at noon to-day. I'll get to Charlottesville to-night, and that'll give me all day to morrow and half the next day
there. Gee! I'm a lucky dog. Al! that time with Bab."
Then he let his horse walk slowly along, while he sat lost in silent thought,
paying not the least attention to animal or road. Probably he was dreaming
of Bab, for when he spoke again it was to ask himself slowly, "I wonder if
she's changed much since spring. Yes, I reckon she's grown up entirely now,
or she wouldn't be writing so much about that Major. Wonder who he is,
anyhow?"
Another pause, and then in a decided tone, "Don't think I like him.
Hello! There's somebody ahead. Get up, Bill."
The man ahead slowed his horse at the sound of a stranger's voice, and
half turned in his saddle to greet him. Evidently he did not recognize the newcomer, however, for instead of speaking to him he sat silently gazing at him;
but the young man approached nevertheless with a polite "Good evening, sir."
"Good evening," answered the other shortly, yet not disagreeably.
At the sound of the man's voice, the boy reined his horse back sharply,
and cried in a tone of surprise, "Oh! I didn't know it was:you!" Then, after
a moment's hesitation, he spurred his horse nearer, and said, Mr. Lindsay—"
"Major Lindsay," corrected the other somewhat haughtily, in a tone that
betrayed no recognition.
"Well, Major Lindsay then, I'm Gordon Chapman. Do you remember
me?" Then there was a slight tremor in his voice as he continued, "And do
you remember what I told you the last time we saw each other?"
"Yes," answered Lindsay in a manner that indicated his reluctance to
believe that what Gordon said was true.
you waive your rank and fight, then? I must keep my promise."

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

"Yes." This time the tone was that of a man assenting to an unpleasant
proposition.
They fired several shots before dismounting, and several more after reaching the ground, the width of the road between them, but neither was hurt, for
both were students, more used to books than bloodshed. Then Major Lindsay
calmly put up his pistols, and declared his cartridges gone. "We can finish
With swords, though," he suggested.
"I have no sword, but we can finish with what God gave both of us—
fists," Gordon replied excitedly. He was eager for the fight,—the fight he had
fought many a time in his imagination.
The match was not an even one, for it was still a man against a boy; the
man, thirty-three years old, strong with the strength of a man nearing his
Prime; the boy, a mere stripling, one who had always cared more for books
than play.
When Major Lindsay rode off, he was cursing "the little fool" for making
"do
him
it whether or no;" and Gordon was slowly and painfully rising from
the trampled ground, at the same time promising himself that "next time"
things would be different.
In war-time a battered face passes without any questions; so by eight
o'clock, Gordon found himself where he had been again and again in fancy—
seated by Bab, in the moonlight, on the old stone steps with the big urns leading down into the garden. One thing, however, was not as it was wont to be
in Dreamland. There he was softly telling Bab that he was a man now, the
war had matured him quickly, and that she was his Bab. Then he would tell
her how she had been his Queen from his first school days, when she had fought
Lindsay for him, clear up to his University years, and that it was for her that
he was working so hard, working that he might lay some laurels at her feet.
But now the war was on and he might never win those laurels; so he must lay
himself at her feet, and beg her to take him as he was. And then Bab had
always laid her head on his shoulder and called him "her own, own Jordie,"
and then he had always kissed her. But now Bab was saying, "Jordie, you
dear old boy, I've got a secret for you. Maybe its the last one we'll have
together, so listen now, and don't you tell a soul. I'm engaged. You're the
only one that knows it. Jordie, it's to Major Lindsay, and he's lots nicer than
he used to be. Oh! I do love him, and you are going to like him for me. 0
Jordie, if you only knew how I love him."
When Gordon reported to his captain, there was still a day and a half of
unexpired leave to his credit.
Two days later there was a great battle. A whole day it raged, and when
night fell, it seemed as if the Confederate army had been scattered to the four
winds of Heaven. In the reports, both Lindsay and Gordon were reported
missing; but the second day after the battle Major Lindsay, wounded in the
Shoulder, made his way into camp, mounted on Gordon's horse. The next
‘rePorts contained M ,jor Lindsay's name among the "Found," and among the
'Dead" was the name of Gordon Chapman.
Lindsay had to be taken to Charlottesville, to the hospital there, and Bab
nursed him. There, one evening he told Bab, "Bab, you got the wrong man.
Chaprnan was worth ten of me. If it hadn't been for him, I'd 've been where he is
now. He died so I could get back to you; when he died he was singing sort of
to himself,'How I love him, how I love him, if you only knew how I love
him•" And just before he died, he whispered to me,'That's what she told me
about you, and it won't go out of my head.' Then he went on singing slower,
and more softly, and finally it just faded away altogether."
,
There was not a sound except that a tall red haired girl was crying softly,
0 Jordie, Jordie."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
NINETY-TWO'S DECENNIAL.

N the evening of April the twelfth, twenty-six members of this ten-year
old class gathered at the Johns Hopkins Club on Park Avenue in their
Tenth Annual Reunion. The attendance was not confined to Baltimore
men. Flying trips from Florida, Ohio, New York and Pennsylvania were made
by those who felt they could not let this particular reunion go by without being
on hand. They were busy men, but each made a personal sacrifice to be present, and planned the trip weeks in advance.
The committee provided an elaborate menu, some good "coon" music and
just a little "free licker," and everybody enjoyed a jolly good evening. There
were no set toasts, the speechifying being very informal and every one taking a
hand, as the notice read, in singing a song, telling a story, or doing some other
"stunt."
It has been often asked how the class has succeeded in keeping up its annual reunions, and what brings men hundreds of miles to attend a class dinner.
The reason is probably not very hard to find and dates back to the year of
grace 1889, when a right fresh lot of candidates succeeded in worrying through
the matriculation examinations of the J. H. U., or enough of them to permit
attendance on the college courses and the class meetings. The latter were not
mere matters of form, but were lively red hot meetings where every man had
his say and through which all class organizations and affairs were activily con
trolled and governed.
Cliques were unknown among us; the democratic rule of the class meeting
was a real one and unfettered. This state of affairs naturally encouraged a general participation in all class matters. Was a scrub team needed to practice the
foot ball team? They turned out almost en masse, with coats inside out in lieu of
canvas jackets (some with pants ditto), and lent a hand in withstanding the
rushes of the regular team. Did one of the fellows get into trouble with the
faculty in his efforts to enliven the hours of L. E. P.*? His name could not be
obtained from any of his classmates, and the whole affair was finally a closed
incident, largely through the efforts of a class committee duly selected to take
the matter up with the faculty, and who pledged, in the event of immunity
from punishment to the offender, the honor of the class against a repetition of the
offense. Was it a class book to publish? Studies were not allowed, even among
the honor men, to interfere with their participation in the arduous duties of the
editorial staff.
The literary and other contributions were numerous, and as a result of a
hearty and earnest co operation the class points with pride to its "Hullabaloo,"
the first class book hearing that name, which, by the way, has since been the
synonym at Hopkins for class book.
Enough has been said to make the point that the old class spirit and good
feeling, which the former inter-class athletic contests did much to strengthen,
had formed after three years a bond of something more than the ordinary ties
* "L. E. P." was the current abbreviation in the last century for Dr. Griffin's course in

O

Logic, Ethics, and Philosophy.

5

of classmates, and at the graduation dinner the sentiment .was commonly expressed that those present were bound together by associations they could not
bear to sunder.
"The Annual Reunion of '92" with hour and place added, is the brief notice sent yearly to each class man. He has been to previous gatherings and needs
no bill of particulars. He knows there awaits him a delightful evening of communion with those who were his constant associates at the University in studies,
athletics, "horse-play" and everything else that was "doing" in the three years
of the college life.
With is teachers and 10 engineers, the class is made up of a baker's dozen
each of lawyers and doctors, four merchants, two men in the government employ, a preacher, an editor, an insurance man and McKay. McKay is variously
reported as a missionary among the Utah Mormons, a plain citizen in their
midst who has placed his limit at but one wife, and as a backslider who has
Yielded to the temptations of his surroundings and taken unto himself a plurality
of consorts. The writer frankly states that he believes these rumors to be all
equally unreliable and hopes that some one who knows will write to the editor
of the NEWS-LETTER and relieve the uncertainty surrounding McKay's location,
vocation, and domestic tastes.
About one.half of the class is married (one wife each) with two about to
renounce celibacy, and the outlook is favorable for a continued accession to the
ranks of the benedicts.
The remarkable record of but one death, which occurred at the very outset
of our career, we trust will not be altered for many decades.
While an unusually large proportion of the men have already achieved success from the worldly standpoint it is our proudest boast that every man, in his
particular pursuit and sphere, is making a worthy and honorable record.
Very many of the readers of the NEWS-LETTER are undergraduates who
have all their reunions to look forward to. The class of '92 sincerely hopes
that its own record in this line will induce every class of our Alma Mater to
The social and pleasurable side of these gatherings
emulate its example.

A word as to our organization, in conclusion, might be helpful to other
classes: Selecting two men who had filled the respective offices in our undergraduate days and were willing to shoulder the recurring duties of their
positions, they were elected Perpetual President and Permanent Secretary,
respectively, of the class organization, and upon them practically rested the
responsibility of the successive annual gatherings.
Originally, a committee existed for this purpose, but to it gradually attached
the prefix "useless," and it drifted by easy stages into the realm of "innocuous
desuetude," whence, after a decade's sojourn, it was summoned to lend a hand
in the preparations attendant upon our greatest reunion, the '92 Decennial.

LESTER L. STEVENS, '92.

HE article on "Ninety-two's Decennial," appearing elsewhere in this issue,
gives much food for thought to every class at the University, and, perhaps, to some that have graduated. '92 is alone among the older Hopkins classes in her proud record of an unbroken line of well-attended class reunions. The story of how she did it should be beneficial to all other aspiring classes,—especially when the tale is told by one so well qualified as Mr.
Stevens, who is the "Perpetual Secretary" referred to in his article.

O

N another page is found the voice of a dissenter to the plea which appeared
in our last issue for an honor system in Hopkins examinations. How
far this represents the sentiment of the student body it is impossible at
present to say, and it will be impossible until such sentiment is sounded. A
plan suggested is a personal canvass of the three classes by their respective
secretaries, the report to be handed in to the presidents of the classes, who shall
form a committee with power to count the votes and decide the majority. It is
understood that this first vote will be merely a "yes" or "no," for or against
the adoption of an honor system in the collegiate department of the University.
Action in the matter is expected before the next issue of the NEWS—LUTTER.

HE lacrosse situation is in that pleasing but uncertain state where speculation runs riot for want of facts to check it. Pennsylvania, Hobart, and
Harvard have fallen victims to our deadly team-work; and, in the words
of the rooters, "Columbia is another bait." With Lehigh and Swarthmore,
however, there is a different tale to be told. By means of the easy but deceitful
comparison of scores, an easy victory may be prophecied for the Black and
Blue; Hobart, one of our "easy marks," beat Lehigh 5-3, and our victory over
1, compares well with Swarthmore's, 8-3. But there is good auHarvard,
thority for distrusting this kind of evidence. Lehigh is an old lacrosse college;
two weeks of outdoor practice, with alumni coaching, will produce a team far
different from the one that went under to Hobart. And as for Swarthmore—
there is last year's story. The splendid capabilities shown by the'02 team will
all be called forth before it can sign itself "Unconquered."

z

T is a custom with most of the leading colleges throughout the country that
there should be published, in the college paper, the reports of the managers
of the various teams, the musical organizations, etc. In accordance with
this custom, there is printed elsewhere in this issue the financial report of the
Musical Clubs for the past season. Good management, economy, and hard
Work are required to pull the organization through a season without leaving
behind a trail of debts. It is pleasing to notice that the credit end of this year's
account was helped materially by the splendid support given the Clubs at the
Baltimore Concert by the Hopkins students themselves,—a support which was
a fine example of loyalty to a college institution, and deserves to be repeated.
The non-serious side of the Musical Clubs is so much brought out that
their actual raison d'etre is often forgotten. On the scholastic side, our University needs no advertising. On the athletic side, our credit for hard work
and fine achievements is known abroad. But there are many, at our very doors,
who need to be told that attention is paid here, not only to the cultivation of
the mind, not merely to the improvement of the body, but also to the development of sociability and congeniality,—all that goes to make up "college life."
To all such the Musical Clubs have a mission to fulfil,—and especially now,
With the approaching growth in importance of our undergraduate body.

3

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
An article appearing in your last issue entitled "The Honor System" has
caused considerable comment among the students. Having discussed the question with graduates of other colleges as to the conditions prevailing in their respective schools, and being in touch with the workings of our collegiate department, I feel that I must dissent from the views expressed in the above mentioned article.
In the first place, there is no need at Hopkins of any so-called system.
We are fortunate to have obtained the distinction of being a college where there
exists among the students a high sense of honor. Elsewhere men for some
mysterious reason do not deem it dishonorable to cheat at examinations, nor

THE NEWS-LETTER.
do they condemn their classmates who do cheat. At Hopkins there is little or
no cheating done in examinations, and those men who do it are looked down
upon by the whole student body.
Secondly, if there were such corruption here, would an "honor system" be
advantageous? If a man thinks it not wrong to secure aid in his examinations,
would he have such a fine sense of honor as not to lie about it? I think the
remedy inadequate.
Furtherfnore, despite the precedents at other universities, there is, I think,
a tendency to lessen a man's self respect, if he must add his oath to every statement he utters. I for one would consider it an insult, if I were asked to sign
any pledge like the one suggested.
An "honor system" is not needed by us, because we have a high standard
of moral sense; and those "black sheep" that would be inclined to cheat are
deterred from so acting for fear of losing the respect of their classmates. If
such a pledge were introduced, it would lessen the dignity of our student body,
and prove inefficacious in remedying any possible evil.
Yours sincerely,

Ross

DIGGS, 1902.

DR. GILMAN'S TRIP TO EUROPE.

R.

GILMAN sailed from New York last week for Europe. He goes partly
for recreation and primarily in the interests cf the Carnegie Institute.
Dr. Gilman will visit the great British and Continental Universities, in
order to acquaint himself with their methods. Speaking of his trip, Dr. Gilman
said:
"I anticipate a very pleasant journey, and hope in my visits to the several
educational centres of the Old World to lay hold on some new ideas, new inspirations and improved methods for the management of an institution designed
for the higher education of Americans. The lines upon which the Carnegie endowment has been planned make it essential that all the knowledge possible on
the subject should be at our disposal, and for this reason my instructions are to
visit every university in Europe and seek to ascertain the special elements of
its strength.''
Dr. Gilman will not return until October.

W. J. Bryan, '03, has been elected assistant manager of the musical clubs.
The Hullabaloo Club has adopted a brief constitution. The Board of Governors is to be self-perpetuating, each member choosing his own successor, with
the approval of his colleagues.
The first "smoker" of the club, held in the Trophy Room on the evening
Monday
last, was attended by almost the whole class, and was a splendid
of
success.

On the afternoon of the r5th Dr. Jacob H. Hollander lectured before the
Arundell Club, on the present conditions in the island of Porto Rico The
lecture was illustrated with many excellent stereopticon views.
After several weeks' postponement, Dr. Woods delivered his lecture on
"Liquid Air," April ro. Having a large amount of liquid air, he was able to
show many interesting experiments. A large audience of students and strangers packed the physical lecture room.
Dr. James N. Schonler, of Boston, is delivering a series of four lectures on
the general subject, "The Life of the People During the Revolution." The
last lecture will be delivered on Friday, the 25th. Dr. Scholller is best known
as the author of "History of the United States Under the Constitution."
In a short time a fifty foot steel tower will be erected on the Weather
Bureau building. The tower, which will be surmounted by a wind vane, will
be higher than the City College.
Mr Frederick I„ Olmsted delivered a lecture in McCoy Hall, last Saturday night, on "The Plan for the Improvement of the City of Washington." The
lecture was delivered under the auspices of the Municipal Art Society.
At the banquet of the Baltimore Alumni Association of the University of
Virginia, held at the Stafford Hotel on April ro, President Remsen responded to
the toast, "Our Sister University." A number of other Hopkins men were in
attendance.
The Hopkins Board of Trustees has received a valuable addition in the five
new trustees, who were elected at a meeting on the 7th of this month, to fill the
vacancies caused by the deaths of Messrs. C. Morton Stewart, Benjamin F.
Newcomer, J. H. Pheasants, and Dr. James Carey Thomas, and by the resignation of Mr. James L. McLane. The new trustees are Mr. Brent Keyser, Mr.
Blanchard Randall, Mr. Theodore Marburg, Mr. Bernard N. Baker, and Mr.
Francis M. Jencks. By the influence and position of these gentlemen, it is
thought that the interests of the University will be materially furthered.
Competition for the Tocqueville gold medal is now open. This medal is
annually given by Baron de Coubertin, of Paris, to the University to be awarded
to that student "who shall have written the best essay on some subject illustrating any phase of French history, political or social, from 1815 to 1890, or a
review of some important historical work published in France since 1890."
The essays, which are to be from 8,000 to i6,000 words long, must be sent to

10

THE NEWS—LETTER.

the Registrar before the first of May. The award will be announced on Commencement Day. Only once has the medal been awarded,—to J. E. Routh,
'oo. The present competition is looked forward to with great interest.
On the shelves of "New Books" is to be found a recently published work
by Dr. J. C. Ballagh, of the Historical Department, entitled "A History of
Slavery in Virginia."
President Rernsen was in New York on Saturday last, attending the in.
auguration of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia. Among
other Hopkins men with him was Mr. Nicholas Murray, librarian of the University, who is a near relative of President Butler.

THE HULLABALOO ELECTIONS.
On Thursday, the seventeenth, the Junior class held an election to select
editors for the 1903 "Hullabaloo." It was a hot one. Almost every office
was fought for with a grim determination, showing that every one was in earnest. Those chosen were: Editor in-chief, R. S. Lanier; Associate Editor.inchief, H. K. Tootle; Associate Literary Editors, C. M. Sparrow, G. D. Strayer,
T. W. Glocker, J. M. Combs, W. M. Hunley, J. A. Addison; Art Editors, J.
Alan Houghton, Wilton Snowien; Business Manager, W. S. Bird; Assistant
Business Managers, P. R. Straus, F. Hazlehurst.
On the whole, it is a splendid board, and should uphold the reputation of the
Junior class—no easy task, as the editors will find to their cost.

HOPKINS IN CIVIC STRIFE.
A.
,
,s M. THOMSON,'97, one of the founders of the NEWS-LETTER, and
a member of its first staff, is at present engaged in a thrilling fight with
the gamblers and Sunday liquor-sellers of Norfolk, Va., in his capacity
as editor of the Norfolk Dispatch. Mr. Thomson, who went into the newspaper
business on his graduation from the University, has been remarkably successful
during his two years charge of the Dispatch, doubling its size and its circulation.
A sudden snag was struck, licwever, in this crusade against the law-breakers of
Norfolk. A prominent crook known as Napoleon Joynes, whom Mr. Thomson had referred to as "the Napoleon of the joints," secured the aid of two
trusty thugs, and made a personal assault upon the editor and members of his
staff, threatening to break up the paper unless retraction of the epithet was
made. The plucky editor's reply was to arrest the assailants and have them
bound to the peace, to obtain permission from the judge to carry arms, and to
prosecute his fight with renewed vigor.
Many expressions of sympathy with Mr. Thomson, and encouragement in
fight he is putting up, have reached the NEWS-LETTER staff, all of

HOPKINS 12, HOBART 1.
is the one word which most aptly describes the whole situation
44INCH!"
e
at the American League Park on April 12. Hobart College came here
for the first time from Geneva, N. Y., with quite a reputation, having
beaten, during the same week, Lehigh, 5-3, and Pennsylvania, 2- 0. Hopkins
very naturally expected a lively struggle in the opening game, but, -as some one
said after the contest, "it was like robbing a child's bank."
Judging from the game which the visitors put up during the two twentyminute halves, it will always be a mystery how they ever defeated Lehigh or
Pennsylvania. Some said that they were overtrained, the contest in Baltimore
being the last on their Southern trip. There is possibly a little in this, but the
work of the team in general was decidedly off color. The stick work was
extremely poor, exhibitions of team play were few and far between, and all the
men lacked ginger and snap. Hopkins, on the other hand, gave the loyal band
of rooters present abundant opportunities for all-around handshaking.
The men started off on the jump, and in thirty seconds little Bernheim
drove the ball in the cage. Putts soon followed suit, and by the end of the
half, the score stood 7 to 0 in Hopkins' favor. During these twenty minutes,
Abercrombie was always at the right spot with both feet, and the rest of the
attack ably assisted him. The few chances which the defense got to feed on

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

the ball found it quite equal to the occasion, and the attack generally had the
sphere returned to them in short order.
Between the halves Coach Abercrombie and Captain Schmeisser impressed
upon the team the great value of the practice which might be gotten out of the
last half. The attack were instructed to pass carefully, and to see that every
man got in the team play necessary for the advancement of the ball. Five
more goals resulted. About the middle of the half, Hobart got one of her few
chances to shoot. The ball struck the goal post, and, as it bounded out, the
inhome man scooped it in the net. One of the Hobart players is reported to
have shouted in an ecstacy of delight: "We got a goal!" And he may well
have shouted, for Hobart was clearly outplayed all around throughout the
entire game.
Although early in the season, the Hopkins men all seemed to have very
good powers of endurance. This is, indeed, a matter of congratulation, for had
we been equal in strength last season to Swarthmore, we should certainly have
won the championship of the United States. With this in our favor, we should
certainly give our victors of last season a "warm reception" on May 10. The
line-up against Hobart College was as follows: Putts, inhome; B. Bernheini,
outhome; Sayler, first attack; Bird, second attack; P. Bernheim, third attack;
Abercrombie, center; Tough, third defense; Blanck, second defense; H.
Straus, first defense; E. Schmeisser, cover point; W. Schmeisser (Captain)
point; Briscoe, goal.
Our alumni delegate, Dr. B. B. Lanier, acted as referee.

OUR VICTORY OVER HARVARD.
HE decisive victory of our lacrosse team over Harvard on April igth came
somewhat as a surprise, for, although we hardly looked forward to a defeat, still a close game was expected and the score of II to L was a matter of hearty congratulation.
Our victory over the Cambridge team last season was gained by 4 goals to
0, and it is well known that lacrosse is steadily gaining ground at Harvard.
That we were going to meet a stronger team than that of last season we felt
assured. The only inference to be drawn, therefore, is that Hopkins is decidedly stronger this year.
It took very little time after the beginning of the game to see that Hopkins was pursuing her old policy of trying to score first and gain a comfortable lead in the first half. Every man went in on the jump, and in less than
three minutes Putts placed the first goal in the net. This seemed to start the
ball, and by the end of the half, the score stood 8 to 0 in Hopkins' favor. Such
a condition of affairs was indeed a surprise to the Hopkins, for in the Hobart
game of a week before, only ;7 goals were made in the first half, and Harvard
was considered much stronger than Hobart. In the second half, Harvard
changed her goal keeper, and Henry Straus retired on account of a wrenched
ankle which he received in the first half. Both changes proved a decided disadvantage to Hopkins. Harvard's new man was decidedly better than the

first, who, by the way, had been wired to come to Baltimore from Cambridge
especially for the game here. The absence of Straus was also keenly felt, for
had he been in the game it is hardly likely that Alvord would have been left
uncovered to shoot the only goal which Harvard scored.
The visitors seemed to be in very good condition, but were unable to break
up the fast team play which Hopkins exhibited at every stage of the contest.
Several of the goals were made strictly in accordance with the theory of the
game, the fourth one passing to and from every man on the attack. The play
called forth hearty applause from the spectators.

E. Schemeisser, cover point; W. Schemeisser, point; Briscoe, goal.
Mr. Henry Penniman, an old Hopkins lacrosse player, acted as referee.

BASE BALL.
GETTYSBURG 9, HOPKINS 2.
T WAS to be expected that the strong Gettysburg College team would defeat
Hopkins in the game of April 12th, but it was not so sure with l.r.:Av much
credit our men would play. For a whole week previous, wet grounds
prevented any outdoor practice. Speaking broadly, the game was satisfactory
to the men, and a great improvement over that played at Annapolis. Five of
the opponents' runs were the direct result of wild throws. Whipple was in
splendid form, and gave only four clean hits and two scratches. It is doubtful
whether Gettysburg earned more than one of the nine runs.
.
The pitching on both sides was excellent, and one of the chief features of
the game. Besides this, Moore's play at second base in blocking runners trying to steal, was beauti`ul to see. Moto, for Gettysburg, made the prettiest
hit of the game—a three bagger over McKnights' head.
Tne fair weather of the past ten days has been made the most of by the

J

team. Practice has been held every afternoon, and more team work and confidence begins to manifest itself. It is more and more apparent that Hopkins
has the material for a splendid team. What is needed is practice, and as soon
as the fielding reaches the standard of the pitching, every Hopkins man may be
proud of the team.

No game could be secured for April r 9, but on the 26th the team will play
the Maryland Athletic Club at College Park. This should be a victory for
Hopkins, and it is hoped that a number of rooters will go along to cheer.
The Base Ball team has received from the Board of Editors of the 1901
Hullabaloo, through its business manager, Mr. Harry S. .13 .rne, a gift of ,40.00,
A
to be used for new uniforms The officers of the team are all grateful for the
interest that has been taken in its career, and are anxious to make a record that
will please everybody. The men think that the worst game has been played,
and that better things are ahead.
THE DEBATING ASSOCIATION.
GRATIFYING outcome of the present Hopkins spirit is the debating
association which has recently been formed. The object of this association is to prepare men to take part in the intercollegiate debates, and
to develop any talent in speaking which the men may have. The officers are:
Harvey B. Stone, president; G. D. Strayer, secretary. According to the constitution, which is now being drawn up, those eligible for membership are the
eighteen men from the Senior .and the Junior classes who make up the class

4
teams

Au important power of the association is the conferring of "H's" upon

the speakers in the intercollegiate debates. In order to distinguish these
"H's" from those of the athletic association, they will be blue instead of yellow. The first rnAn upon whom the blue "H" will be conferred are Messrs.
Stone and Plaggemeyer, the two presidents of the Senior and Junior classes,
who represented the University in her late struggle with North Carolina.

ALUMNI.
Mr. Henry Clay Miller, of the class of 1901, was married to Miss Katherine
Fauntlery, of Stanton, Va., on April 8. On their return from the wedding trip,
Mr. and Mrs. Miller will reside in Stanton.
R. I, McAll, 'oo, has accepted a position as organist in a church connected
with the Brick Presbyterian Church, New York City. Mr. McAll will enter on
his duties in October.
The class of 1900 will hold an informal banquet at the Hopkins Club on the
night of the 25th.

No, 14.

THE LOVE OF A LAD FOR A LASS.
HERE was the subdued hum of children studying in the small Virginia
school-room. From without came the chirping of a robin perched among
the blossoms of the peach tree that scraped its branches lazily against the
.
window of the school-house. By the side of the teacher, a young man, stood a
Slight, black-haired boy of ten, engrossed in the explanation of a sum on his
Slate. The heads of both master and scholar were bent over the slate, so that
neither noticed a boy in the back of the room quietly filling a squirt-gun from
the water-bucket. Twice or thrice at some slight noise the teacher glanced up
angrily, and once he knocked loudly on the desk with a ruler, but still the
little rascal with the gun went undetected; and, judging from the way the
smallest noise disturbed the teacher, it was well for the boy that his more repreprehensible act did go unnoticed. Then, while every pupil held his breath,
Partly in admiration, partly in fear, a thin stream of water shot across the room
and broke on the teacher's head, splashing over the book-covered desk before
him. Completely taken aback by the unexpected bath, the teacher sprang up,
anger flushing every feature, and made a step toward, to his mind, the one possible culprit, the boy who had been standing by the desk, but who had jumped
back, as much astonished at the splashing water as the teacher himself had been.
"Gordon Chapman," he burst out, "you did that!"
Slap! and Gordon was lying in a heap across the platform, his face sheetWhite except where four finger-marks blazed fiercely out.
"Stop! You— you— devil! Jordie didn't do it." As Gordon went to
the floor under his master's hand, a little red-haired girl of about his age, hurling at the teacher the vilest name she could think of, jumped on the platform,
and with childish rage attempted to dig her finger nails into his face.
"Don't, Bab, don't," Gordon pleaded weakly from the floor; "he'll slap
you, too. Stop!"
Seeing that the disturbance was developing into a rebellion, the teacher
calmed himself sufficiently to proclaim the dismission of school. "Gordon
Chapman will remain, though," he said, "and Miss Barbara's mother shall
know of her daughter's behavior before to-night." All of the scholars except
Bab. and Gordon gleefully departed; Bab tearfully and unwillingly stumbled
out the door, calling back words of consolation and encouragement to poor
Jorclie, who sat with pale cheeks but tightly held lips, awaiting whatever was
to come.
When two University students, alarmed by Bab's confused story, arrived
at the school-house half an hour later, they found Gordon, with bloody stripes

t

across the back of his shirt-waist, lying in a faint on the :floor, and by him a
broken rattan.
One afternoon of the following week, the school-room door was opened,
and Gordon Chapman, four blue bruises across his face, walked somewhat uncertainly up the aisle, under the wondering gaze of his schoolmates.
"Mr. Lindsay," he said, as strongly as he could, "I'm not coming here
any longer to school, but I'll never forget you; and as soon as I am able I am
going to kill you."
As he strode down the aisle, now with a manly step, and passed out the
door, no one made a sound except that a little red-haired girl cried softly, "0
Jordie, Jordiel"
Eight years had passed since Gordon Chapman had made his promise to
Roger Lindsay; the great Civil War was just beginning, and many tented
cities, peopled with Virginia's sons, both young and old, had sprung up as in
a single night. It was about five o'clock of a warm August afternoon; a boy,
not quite grown, wearing the uniform of a Confederate private, was riding
slowly along the wooded road, singing an old love song. Presently he stopped
singing and began to calculate.
"Let's see, three days' leave, beginning at noon to-day. I'll get to Charlottesville to-night, and that'll give me all day to morrow and half the next day
there. Gee! I'm a lucky dog. Al! that time with Bab."
Then he let his horse walk slowly along, while he sat lost in silent thought,
paying not the least attention to animal or road. Probably he was dreaming
of Bab, for when he spoke again it was to ask himself slowly, "I wonder if
she's changed much since spring. Yes, I reckon she's grown up entirely now,
or she wouldn't be writing so much about that Major. Wonder who he is,
anyhow?"
Another pause, and then in a decided tone, "Don't think I like him.
Hello! There's somebody ahead. Get up, Bill."
The man ahead slowed his horse at the sound of a stranger's voice, and
half turned in his saddle to greet him. Evidently he did not recognize the newcomer, however, for instead of speaking to him he sat silently gazing at him;
but the young man approached nevertheless with a polite "Good evening, sir."
"Good evening," answered the other shortly, yet not disagreeably.
At the sound of the man's voice, the boy reined his horse back sharply,
and cried in a tone of surprise, "Oh! I didn't know it was:you!" Then, after
a moment's hesitation, he spurred his horse nearer, and said, Mr. Lindsay—"
"Major Lindsay," corrected the other somewhat haughtily, in a tone that
betrayed no recognition.
"Well, Major Lindsay then, I'm Gordon Chapman. Do you remember
me?" Then there was a slight tremor in his voice as he continued, "And do
you remember what I told you the last time we saw each other?"
"Yes," answered Lindsay in a manner that indicated his reluctance to
believe that what Gordon said was true.
you waive your rank and fight, then? I must keep my promise."

"Yes." This time the tone was that of a man assenting to an unpleasant
proposition.
They fired several shots before dismounting, and several more after reaching the ground, the width of the road between them, but neither was hurt, for
both were students, more used to books than bloodshed. Then Major Lindsay
calmly put up his pistols, and declared his cartridges gone. "We can finish
With swords, though," he suggested.
"I have no sword, but we can finish with what God gave both of us—
fists," Gordon replied excitedly. He was eager for the fight,—the fight he had
fought many a time in his imagination.
The match was not an even one, for it was still a man against a boy; the
man, thirty-three years old, strong with the strength of a man nearing his
Prime; the boy, a mere stripling, one who had always cared more for books
than play.
When Major Lindsay rode off, he was cursing "the little fool" for making
"do
him
it whether or no;" and Gordon was slowly and painfully rising from
the trampled ground, at the same time promising himself that "next time"
things would be different.
In war-time a battered face passes without any questions; so by eight
o'clock, Gordon found himself where he had been again and again in fancy—
seated by Bab, in the moonlight, on the old stone steps with the big urns leading down into the garden. One thing, however, was not as it was wont to be
in Dreamland. There he was softly telling Bab that he was a man now, the
war had matured him quickly, and that she was his Bab. Then he would tell
her how she had been his Queen from his first school days, when she had fought
Lindsay for him, clear up to his University years, and that it was for her that
he was working so hard, working that he might lay some laurels at her feet.
But now the war was on and he might never win those laurels; so he must lay
himself at her feet, and beg her to take him as he was. And then Bab had
always laid her head on his shoulder and called him "her own, own Jordie,"
and then he had always kissed her. But now Bab was saying, "Jordie, you
dear old boy, I've got a secret for you. Maybe its the last one we'll have
together, so listen now, and don't you tell a soul. I'm engaged. You're the
only one that knows it. Jordie, it's to Major Lindsay, and he's lots nicer than
he used to be. Oh! I do love him, and you are going to like him for me. 0
Jordie, if you only knew how I love him."
When Gordon reported to his captain, there was still a day and a half of
unexpired leave to his credit.
Two days later there was a great battle. A whole day it raged, and when
night fell, it seemed as if the Confederate army had been scattered to the four
winds of Heaven. In the reports, both Lindsay and Gordon were reported
missing; but the second day after the battle Major Lindsay, wounded in the
Shoulder, made his way into camp, mounted on Gordon's horse. The next
‘rePorts contained M ,jor Lindsay's name among the "Found," and among the
'Dead" was the name of Gordon Chapman.
Lindsay had to be taken to Charlottesville, to the hospital there, and Bab
nursed him. There, one evening he told Bab, "Bab, you got the wrong man.
Chaprnan was worth ten of me. If it hadn't been for him, I'd 've been where he is
now. He died so I could get back to you; when he died he was singing sort of
to himself,'How I love him, how I love him, if you only knew how I love
him•" And just before he died, he whispered to me,'That's what she told me
about you, and it won't go out of my head.' Then he went on singing slower,
and more softly, and finally it just faded away altogether."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
NINETY-TWO'S DECENNIAL.

N the evening of April the twelfth, twenty-six members of this ten-year
old class gathered at the Johns Hopkins Club on Park Avenue in their
Tenth Annual Reunion. The attendance was not confined to Baltimore
men. Flying trips from Florida, Ohio, New York and Pennsylvania were made
by those who felt they could not let this particular reunion go by without being
on hand. They were busy men, but each made a personal sacrifice to be present, and planned the trip weeks in advance.
The committee provided an elaborate menu, some good "coon" music and
just a little "free licker," and everybody enjoyed a jolly good evening. There
were no set toasts, the speechifying being very informal and every one taking a
hand, as the notice read, in singing a song, telling a story, or doing some other
"stunt."
It has been often asked how the class has succeeded in keeping up its annual reunions, and what brings men hundreds of miles to attend a class dinner.
The reason is probably not very hard to find and dates back to the year of
grace 1889, when a right fresh lot of candidates succeeded in worrying through
the matriculation examinations of the J. H. U., or enough of them to permit
attendance on the college courses and the class meetings. The latter were not
mere matters of form, but were lively red hot meetings where every man had
his say and through which all class organizations and affairs were activily con
trolled and governed.
Cliques were unknown among us; the democratic rule of the class meeting
was a real one and unfettered. This state of affairs naturally encouraged a general participation in all class matters. Was a scrub team needed to practice the
foot ball team? They turned out almost en masse, with coats inside out in lieu of
canvas jackets (some with pants ditto), and lent a hand in withstanding the
rushes of the regular team. Did one of the fellows get into trouble with the
faculty in his efforts to enliven the hours of L. E. P.*? His name could not be
obtained from any of his classmates, and the whole affair was finally a closed
incident, largely through the efforts of a class committee duly selected to take
the matter up with the faculty, and who pledged, in the event of immunity
from punishment to the offender, the honor of the class against a repetition of the
offense. Was it a class book to publish? Studies were not allowed, even among
the honor men, to interfere with their participation in the arduous duties of the
editorial staff.
The literary and other contributions were numerous, and as a result of a
hearty and earnest co operation the class points with pride to its "Hullabaloo,"
the first class book hearing that name, which, by the way, has since been the
synonym at Hopkins for class book.
Enough has been said to make the point that the old class spirit and good
feeling, which the former inter-class athletic contests did much to strengthen,
had formed after three years a bond of something more than the ordinary ties
* "L. E. P." was the current abbreviation in the last century for Dr. Griffin's course in

"The Annual Reunion of '92" with hour and place added, is the brief notice sent yearly to each class man. He has been to previous gatherings and needs
no bill of particulars. He knows there awaits him a delightful evening of communion with those who were his constant associates at the University in studies,
athletics, "horse-play" and everything else that was "doing" in the three years
of the college life.
With is teachers and 10 engineers, the class is made up of a baker's dozen
each of lawyers and doctors, four merchants, two men in the government employ, a preacher, an editor, an insurance man and McKay. McKay is variously
reported as a missionary among the Utah Mormons, a plain citizen in their
midst who has placed his limit at but one wife, and as a backslider who has
Yielded to the temptations of his surroundings and taken unto himself a plurality
of consorts. The writer frankly states that he believes these rumors to be all
equally unreliable and hopes that some one who knows will write to the editor
of the NEWS-LETTER and relieve the uncertainty surrounding McKay's location,
vocation, and domestic tastes.
About one.half of the class is married (one wife each) with two about to
renounce celibacy, and the outlook is favorable for a continued accession to the
ranks of the benedicts.
The remarkable record of but one death, which occurred at the very outset
of our career, we trust will not be altered for many decades.
While an unusually large proportion of the men have already achieved success from the worldly standpoint it is our proudest boast that every man, in his
particular pursuit and sphere, is making a worthy and honorable record.
Very many of the readers of the NEWS-LETTER are undergraduates who
have all their reunions to look forward to. The class of '92 sincerely hopes
that its own record in this line will induce every class of our Alma Mater to

A word as to our organization, in conclusion, might be helpful to other
classes: Selecting two men who had filled the respective offices in our undergraduate days and were willing to shoulder the recurring duties of their
positions, they were elected Perpetual President and Permanent Secretary,
respectively, of the class organization, and upon them practically rested the
responsibility of the successive annual gatherings.
Originally, a committee existed for this purpose, but to it gradually attached
the prefix "useless," and it drifted by easy stages into the realm of "innocuous
desuetude," whence, after a decade's sojourn, it was summoned to lend a hand
in the preparations attendant upon our greatest reunion, the '92 Decennial.

LESTER L. STEVENS, '92.

HE article on "Ninety-two's Decennial," appearing elsewhere in this issue,
gives much food for thought to every class at the University, and, perhaps, to some that have graduated. '92 is alone among the older Hopkins classes in her proud record of an unbroken line of well-attended class reunions. The story of how she did it should be beneficial to all other aspiring classes,—especially when the tale is told by one so well qualified as Mr.
Stevens, who is the "Perpetual Secretary" referred to in his article.

O

N another page is found the voice of a dissenter to the plea which appeared
in our last issue for an honor system in Hopkins examinations. How
far this represents the sentiment of the student body it is impossible at
present to say, and it will be impossible until such sentiment is sounded. A
plan suggested is a personal canvass of the three classes by their respective
secretaries, the report to be handed in to the presidents of the classes, who shall
form a committee with power to count the votes and decide the majority. It is
understood that this first vote will be merely a "yes" or "no," for or against
the adoption of an honor system in the collegiate department of the University.
Action in the matter is expected before the next issue of the NEWS—LUTTER.

HE lacrosse situation is in that pleasing but uncertain state where speculation runs riot for want of facts to check it. Pennsylvania, Hobart, and
Harvard have fallen victims to our deadly team-work; and, in the words
of the rooters, "Columbia is another bait." With Lehigh and Swarthmore,
however, there is a different tale to be told. By means of the easy but deceitful
comparison of scores, an easy victory may be prophecied for the Black and
Blue; Hobart, one of our "easy marks," beat Lehigh 5-3, and our victory over
1, compares well with Swarthmore's, 8-3. But there is good auHarvard,
thority for distrusting this kind of evidence. Lehigh is an old lacrosse college;
two weeks of outdoor practice, with alumni coaching, will produce a team far
different from the one that went under to Hobart. And as for Swarthmore—
there is last year's story. The splendid capabilities shown by the'02 team will
all be called forth before it can sign itself "Unconquered."

z

T is a custom with most of the leading colleges throughout the country that
there should be published, in the college paper, the reports of the managers
of the various teams, the musical organizations, etc. In accordance with
this custom, there is printed elsewhere in this issue the financial report of the
Musical Clubs for the past season. Good management, economy, and hard
Work are required to pull the organization through a season without leaving
behind a trail of debts. It is pleasing to notice that the credit end of this year's
account was helped materially by the splendid support given the Clubs at the
Baltimore Concert by the Hopkins students themselves,—a support which was
a fine example of loyalty to a college institution, and deserves to be repeated.
The non-serious side of the Musical Clubs is so much brought out that
their actual raison d'etre is often forgotten. On the scholastic side, our University needs no advertising. On the athletic side, our credit for hard work
and fine achievements is known abroad. But there are many, at our very doors,
who need to be told that attention is paid here, not only to the cultivation of
the mind, not merely to the improvement of the body, but also to the development of sociability and congeniality,—all that goes to make up "college life."
To all such the Musical Clubs have a mission to fulfil,—and especially now,
With the approaching growth in importance of our undergraduate body.

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
An article appearing in your last issue entitled "The Honor System" has
caused considerable comment among the students. Having discussed the question with graduates of other colleges as to the conditions prevailing in their respective schools, and being in touch with the workings of our collegiate department, I feel that I must dissent from the views expressed in the above mentioned article.
In the first place, there is no need at Hopkins of any so-called system.
We are fortunate to have obtained the distinction of being a college where there
exists among the students a high sense of honor. Elsewhere men for some
mysterious reason do not deem it dishonorable to cheat at examinations, nor

THE NEWS-LETTER.
do they condemn their classmates who do cheat. At Hopkins there is little or
no cheating done in examinations, and those men who do it are looked down
upon by the whole student body.
Secondly, if there were such corruption here, would an "honor system" be
advantageous? If a man thinks it not wrong to secure aid in his examinations,
would he have such a fine sense of honor as not to lie about it? I think the
remedy inadequate.
Furtherfnore, despite the precedents at other universities, there is, I think,
a tendency to lessen a man's self respect, if he must add his oath to every statement he utters. I for one would consider it an insult, if I were asked to sign
any pledge like the one suggested.
An "honor system" is not needed by us, because we have a high standard
of moral sense; and those "black sheep" that would be inclined to cheat are
deterred from so acting for fear of losing the respect of their classmates. If
such a pledge were introduced, it would lessen the dignity of our student body,
and prove inefficacious in remedying any possible evil.
Yours sincerely,

Ross

DIGGS, 1902.

DR. GILMAN'S TRIP TO EUROPE.

R.

GILMAN sailed from New York last week for Europe. He goes partly
for recreation and primarily in the interests cf the Carnegie Institute.
Dr. Gilman will visit the great British and Continental Universities, in
order to acquaint himself with their methods. Speaking of his trip, Dr. Gilman
said:
"I anticipate a very pleasant journey, and hope in my visits to the several
educational centres of the Old World to lay hold on some new ideas, new inspirations and improved methods for the management of an institution designed
for the higher education of Americans. The lines upon which the Carnegie endowment has been planned make it essential that all the knowledge possible on
the subject should be at our disposal, and for this reason my instructions are to
visit every university in Europe and seek to ascertain the special elements of
its strength.''
Dr. Gilman will not return until October.

W. J. Bryan, '03, has been elected assistant manager of the musical clubs.
The Hullabaloo Club has adopted a brief constitution. The Board of Governors is to be self-perpetuating, each member choosing his own successor, with
the approval of his colleagues.

On the afternoon of the r5th Dr. Jacob H. Hollander lectured before the
Arundell Club, on the present conditions in the island of Porto Rico The
lecture was illustrated with many excellent stereopticon views.
After several weeks' postponement, Dr. Woods delivered his lecture on
"Liquid Air," April ro. Having a large amount of liquid air, he was able to
show many interesting experiments. A large audience of students and strangers packed the physical lecture room.
Dr. James N. Schonler, of Boston, is delivering a series of four lectures on
the general subject, "The Life of the People During the Revolution." The
last lecture will be delivered on Friday, the 25th. Dr. Scholller is best known
as the author of "History of the United States Under the Constitution."
In a short time a fifty foot steel tower will be erected on the Weather
Bureau building. The tower, which will be surmounted by a wind vane, will
be higher than the City College.
Mr Frederick I„ Olmsted delivered a lecture in McCoy Hall, last Saturday night, on "The Plan for the Improvement of the City of Washington." The
lecture was delivered under the auspices of the Municipal Art Society.
At the banquet of the Baltimore Alumni Association of the University of
Virginia, held at the Stafford Hotel on April ro, President Remsen responded to
the toast, "Our Sister University." A number of other Hopkins men were in
attendance.
The Hopkins Board of Trustees has received a valuable addition in the five
new trustees, who were elected at a meeting on the 7th of this month, to fill the
vacancies caused by the deaths of Messrs. C. Morton Stewart, Benjamin F.
Newcomer, J. H. Pheasants, and Dr. James Carey Thomas, and by the resignation of Mr. James L. McLane. The new trustees are Mr. Brent Keyser, Mr.
Blanchard Randall, Mr. Theodore Marburg, Mr. Bernard N. Baker, and Mr.
Francis M. Jencks. By the influence and position of these gentlemen, it is
thought that the interests of the University will be materially furthered.
Competition for the Tocqueville gold medal is now open. This medal is
annually given by Baron de Coubertin, of Paris, to the University to be awarded
to that student "who shall have written the best essay on some subject illustrating any phase of French history, political or social, from 1815 to 1890, or a
review of some important historical work published in France since 1890."
The essays, which are to be from 8,000 to i6,000 words long, must be sent to

10

THE NEWS—LETTER.

the Registrar before the first of May. The award will be announced on Commencement Day. Only once has the medal been awarded,—to J. E. Routh,
'oo. The present competition is looked forward to with great interest.
On the shelves of "New Books" is to be found a recently published work
by Dr. J. C. Ballagh, of the Historical Department, entitled "A History of
Slavery in Virginia."
President Rernsen was in New York on Saturday last, attending the in.
auguration of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia. Among
other Hopkins men with him was Mr. Nicholas Murray, librarian of the University, who is a near relative of President Butler.

THE HULLABALOO ELECTIONS.
On Thursday, the seventeenth, the Junior class held an election to select
editors for the 1903 "Hullabaloo." It was a hot one. Almost every office
was fought for with a grim determination, showing that every one was in earnest. Those chosen were: Editor in-chief, R. S. Lanier; Associate Editor.inchief, H. K. Tootle; Associate Literary Editors, C. M. Sparrow, G. D. Strayer,
T. W. Glocker, J. M. Combs, W. M. Hunley, J. A. Addison; Art Editors, J.
Alan Houghton, Wilton Snowien; Business Manager, W. S. Bird; Assistant
Business Managers, P. R. Straus, F. Hazlehurst.
On the whole, it is a splendid board, and should uphold the reputation of the
Junior class—no easy task, as the editors will find to their cost.

HOPKINS IN CIVIC STRIFE.
A.
,
,s M. THOMSON,'97, one of the founders of the NEWS-LETTER, and
a member of its first staff, is at present engaged in a thrilling fight with
the gamblers and Sunday liquor-sellers of Norfolk, Va., in his capacity
as editor of the Norfolk Dispatch. Mr. Thomson, who went into the newspaper
business on his graduation from the University, has been remarkably successful
during his two years charge of the Dispatch, doubling its size and its circulation.
A sudden snag was struck, licwever, in this crusade against the law-breakers of
Norfolk. A prominent crook known as Napoleon Joynes, whom Mr. Thomson had referred to as "the Napoleon of the joints," secured the aid of two
trusty thugs, and made a personal assault upon the editor and members of his
staff, threatening to break up the paper unless retraction of the epithet was
made. The plucky editor's reply was to arrest the assailants and have them
bound to the peace, to obtain permission from the judge to carry arms, and to
prosecute his fight with renewed vigor.
Many expressions of sympathy with Mr. Thomson, and encouragement in
fight he is putting up, have reached the NEWS-LETTER staff, all of

HOPKINS 12, HOBART 1.
is the one word which most aptly describes the whole situation
44INCH!"
e
at the American League Park on April 12. Hobart College came here
for the first time from Geneva, N. Y., with quite a reputation, having
beaten, during the same week, Lehigh, 5-3, and Pennsylvania, 2- 0. Hopkins
very naturally expected a lively struggle in the opening game, but, -as some one
said after the contest, "it was like robbing a child's bank."
Judging from the game which the visitors put up during the two twentyminute halves, it will always be a mystery how they ever defeated Lehigh or
Pennsylvania. Some said that they were overtrained, the contest in Baltimore
being the last on their Southern trip. There is possibly a little in this, but the
work of the team in general was decidedly off color. The stick work was
extremely poor, exhibitions of team play were few and far between, and all the
men lacked ginger and snap. Hopkins, on the other hand, gave the loyal band
of rooters present abundant opportunities for all-around handshaking.
The men started off on the jump, and in thirty seconds little Bernheim
drove the ball in the cage. Putts soon followed suit, and by the end of the
half, the score stood 7 to 0 in Hopkins' favor. During these twenty minutes,
Abercrombie was always at the right spot with both feet, and the rest of the
attack ably assisted him. The few chances which the defense got to feed on

12

THE NEWS-LETTER.

the ball found it quite equal to the occasion, and the attack generally had the
sphere returned to them in short order.
Between the halves Coach Abercrombie and Captain Schmeisser impressed
upon the team the great value of the practice which might be gotten out of the
last half. The attack were instructed to pass carefully, and to see that every
man got in the team play necessary for the advancement of the ball. Five
more goals resulted. About the middle of the half, Hobart got one of her few
chances to shoot. The ball struck the goal post, and, as it bounded out, the
inhome man scooped it in the net. One of the Hobart players is reported to
have shouted in an ecstacy of delight: "We got a goal!" And he may well
have shouted, for Hobart was clearly outplayed all around throughout the
entire game.
Although early in the season, the Hopkins men all seemed to have very
good powers of endurance. This is, indeed, a matter of congratulation, for had
we been equal in strength last season to Swarthmore, we should certainly have
won the championship of the United States. With this in our favor, we should
certainly give our victors of last season a "warm reception" on May 10. The
line-up against Hobart College was as follows: Putts, inhome; B. Bernheini,
outhome; Sayler, first attack; Bird, second attack; P. Bernheim, third attack;
Abercrombie, center; Tough, third defense; Blanck, second defense; H.
Straus, first defense; E. Schmeisser, cover point; W. Schmeisser (Captain)
point; Briscoe, goal.
Our alumni delegate, Dr. B. B. Lanier, acted as referee.

OUR VICTORY OVER HARVARD.
HE decisive victory of our lacrosse team over Harvard on April igth came
somewhat as a surprise, for, although we hardly looked forward to a defeat, still a close game was expected and the score of II to L was a matter of hearty congratulation.
Our victory over the Cambridge team last season was gained by 4 goals to
0, and it is well known that lacrosse is steadily gaining ground at Harvard.
That we were going to meet a stronger team than that of last season we felt
assured. The only inference to be drawn, therefore, is that Hopkins is decidedly stronger this year.
It took very little time after the beginning of the game to see that Hopkins was pursuing her old policy of trying to score first and gain a comfortable lead in the first half. Every man went in on the jump, and in less than
three minutes Putts placed the first goal in the net. This seemed to start the
ball, and by the end of the half, the score stood 8 to 0 in Hopkins' favor. Such
a condition of affairs was indeed a surprise to the Hopkins, for in the Hobart
game of a week before, only ;7 goals were made in the first half, and Harvard
was considered much stronger than Hobart. In the second half, Harvard
changed her goal keeper, and Henry Straus retired on account of a wrenched
ankle which he received in the first half. Both changes proved a decided disadvantage to Hopkins. Harvard's new man was decidedly better than the

first, who, by the way, had been wired to come to Baltimore from Cambridge
especially for the game here. The absence of Straus was also keenly felt, for
had he been in the game it is hardly likely that Alvord would have been left
uncovered to shoot the only goal which Harvard scored.
The visitors seemed to be in very good condition, but were unable to break
up the fast team play which Hopkins exhibited at every stage of the contest.
Several of the goals were made strictly in accordance with the theory of the
game, the fourth one passing to and from every man on the attack. The play
called forth hearty applause from the spectators.

E. Schemeisser, cover point; W. Schemeisser, point; Briscoe, goal.
Mr. Henry Penniman, an old Hopkins lacrosse player, acted as referee.

BASE BALL.
GETTYSBURG 9, HOPKINS 2.
T WAS to be expected that the strong Gettysburg College team would defeat
Hopkins in the game of April 12th, but it was not so sure with l.r.:Av much
credit our men would play. For a whole week previous, wet grounds
prevented any outdoor practice. Speaking broadly, the game was satisfactory
to the men, and a great improvement over that played at Annapolis. Five of
the opponents' runs were the direct result of wild throws. Whipple was in
splendid form, and gave only four clean hits and two scratches. It is doubtful
whether Gettysburg earned more than one of the nine runs.
.
The pitching on both sides was excellent, and one of the chief features of
the game. Besides this, Moore's play at second base in blocking runners trying to steal, was beauti`ul to see. Moto, for Gettysburg, made the prettiest
hit of the game—a three bagger over McKnights' head.
Tne fair weather of the past ten days has been made the most of by the

J

team. Practice has been held every afternoon, and more team work and confidence begins to manifest itself. It is more and more apparent that Hopkins
has the material for a splendid team. What is needed is practice, and as soon
as the fielding reaches the standard of the pitching, every Hopkins man may be
proud of the team.

No game could be secured for April r 9, but on the 26th the team will play
the Maryland Athletic Club at College Park. This should be a victory for
Hopkins, and it is hoped that a number of rooters will go along to cheer.
The Base Ball team has received from the Board of Editors of the 1901
Hullabaloo, through its business manager, Mr. Harry S. .13 .rne, a gift of ,40.00,
A
to be used for new uniforms The officers of the team are all grateful for the
interest that has been taken in its career, and are anxious to make a record that
will please everybody. The men think that the worst game has been played,
and that better things are ahead.
THE DEBATING ASSOCIATION.
GRATIFYING outcome of the present Hopkins spirit is the debating
association which has recently been formed. The object of this association is to prepare men to take part in the intercollegiate debates, and
to develop any talent in speaking which the men may have. The officers are:
Harvey B. Stone, president; G. D. Strayer, secretary. According to the constitution, which is now being drawn up, those eligible for membership are the
eighteen men from the Senior .and the Junior classes who make up the class

4
teams

Au important power of the association is the conferring of "H's" upon

the speakers in the intercollegiate debates. In order to distinguish these
"H's" from those of the athletic association, they will be blue instead of yellow. The first rnAn upon whom the blue "H" will be conferred are Messrs.
Stone and Plaggemeyer, the two presidents of the Senior and Junior classes,
who represented the University in her late struggle with North Carolina.
